bibl.title: Inaros Son of Petese in the Galleries of Tuna al-Gebel Necropolis.
Acts of the Tenth International Congress of Demotic Studies. Leuven, 26-30 August 2008.

bibl.note: 16 clay vessels from the subterranean galleries of the sacred animals (Ibiotapheion), found by Sami Gabra. They contain remains of ibis bones and eggs, and some linen fragments, and bear a demotic votive text written in black ink. - Introduction. - Style of the rectangular clay vessels. - The texts [Nos 1-16]. - Line commentary. - Palaeographical notes. - Who is Inaros son of Petese? [Probably a man officially involved in religious rites with sacred birds at the Hermopolitan temple area.] - Dating of these texts. [Probably during the native 30th dynasty (Nectanebo I).]
bibl.seg: Mahmoud Ebeid, Inaros Son of Petese in the Galleries of Tuna al-Gebel Necropolis.

Mark Depauw & Yanne Broux (edd.), Acts of the Tenth International Congress of Demotic Studies. Leuven, 26-30 August 2008 = Orientalia Lovaniensia Analecta. 231 (Leuven - Paris - Walpole, MA, 2014) pp. 43-60, 3 figg., 6 pll.

16 clay vessels from the subterranean galleries of the sacred animals (Ibiotapheion), found by Sami Gabra. They contain remains of ibis bones and eggs, and some linen fragments, and bear a demotic votive text written in black ink. - Introduction. - Style of the rectangular clay vessels. - The texts [Nos 1-16]. - Line commentary. - Palaeographical notes. - Who is Inaros son of Petese? [Probably a man officially involved in religious rites with sacred birds at the Hermopolitan temple area.] - Dating of these texts. [Probably during the native 30th dynasty (Nectanebo I).]
